--- title: Data wrangling subtitle: Lecture 7 format: revealjs: default editor_options: chunk_output_type: console execute: warning: false message: false --- ## Study tips for the exam ::: incremental - Go over lecture materials and application exercises - Review labs and feedback you've received so far - Do the exercises at the end of readings from both books - Do the exam review (to be posted on Friday) ::: ## Frequently asked question {.smaller} **Is there a limit to a DataFrame size?** No, a DataFrame can be any number of rows or columns. However, when you print it, it will only print the first few rows and the columns that fit across the screen. If you want to see more rows and columns, you can: - Open it in the data viewer with `df.head(n)` - Explicitly print more rows with, e.g., `print(df.head(25))` - Explicitly select or rearrange columns ## Options for a DataFrame {.smaller} ::: panel-tabset ## Default ::: {#4a411e96 .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd df = 44412 46104 45695 434 19163 19385 19094 435 133950 140320 136822 436 72685 73605 72157 [437 rows x 28 columns] ``` ::: ::: ::: # Data wrangling # Data wrangling
AKA Munging ðŸ¤® # Joining datasets ## Why join? {.smaller} Suppose we want to answer questions like: > Is there a relationship between\ > - number of DS courses taken\ > - motivation for taking course\ > - ...\ > and performance in this course?" . . . Each of these would require *join*ing class performance data with an outside data source so we can have all relevant information (columns) in a single data frame. ## Setup For the next few slides... ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#8c84e6a3 .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = pd.DataFrame({ 'id': [1, 2, 3], 'value_x': ['x1', 'x2', 'x3'] }) print(x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x 0 1 x1 1 2 x2 2 3 x3 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#075bb677 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} y = pd.DataFrame({ 'id': [1, 2, 4], 'value_y': ['y1', 'y2', 'y4'] }) print(y) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_y 0 1 y1 1 2 y2 2 4 y4 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Left join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/left-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#20991088 .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} left_merged = pd.merge(x, y, on='id', how='left') print(left_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x value_y 0 1 x1 y1 1 2 x2 y2 2 3 x3 NaN ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Right join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/right-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#39e69c92 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} right_merged = pd.merge(x, y, on='id', how='right') print(right_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x value_y 0 1 x1 y1 1 2 x2 y2 2 4 NaN y4 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Outer (full) join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/full-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#b8731d42 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} outer_merged = pd.merge(x, y, on='id', how='outer') print(outer_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x value_y 0 1 x1 y1 1 2 x2 y2 2 3 x3 NaN 3 4 NaN y4 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Inner join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/inner-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#35c4374c .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} inner_merged = pd.merge(x, y, on='id', how='inner') print(inner_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x value_y 0 1 x1 y1 1 2 x2 y2 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Semi-join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/semi-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#8392e323 .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} semi_merged = x[x['id'].isin(y['id'])] print(semi_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x 0 1 x1 1 2 x2 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Anti-join ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](images/anti-join.gif) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#6e5067ff .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} anti_merged = x[~x['id'].isin(y['id'])] print(anti_merged) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` id value_x 2 3 x3 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: fragment ðŸ¤® ::: ## Pivoting (`.melt()`) {.smaller} ::: incremental - Data sets can't be labeled as *wide* or *long*, but they can be made *wider* or *longer* for a certain analysis that requires a certain format. - When pivoting longer, variable names that turn into values are characters by default. If you need them to be in another format, you need to explicitly make that transformation, which you can do within the `melt()` function. ::: ## `ae-05-majors-wrangling`
